trial_identification.studytitle: Transthoracic Echocardiography and Transurethral Resection of the Prostate
trial_identification.scientifictitle: High dose versus low dose fluid preloading and the effect on left ventricular volume and function prior to the administration of spinal anaesthesia in patients undergoing transurethral resection of the prostate.

conditions.healthcondition: Left ventricular volume and left ventricular function in patients undergoing transurethral resection of the prostate.

interventions.interventions:
All patients receive 5 ml/kg of 0.9% sodium chloride as a standard fluid loading regime. The intervention group receives a further 10 ml/kg of 0.9% sodium chloride intravenously.
The intravenous fluid is administered until each patient has reached the specific amount calculated by thier weight. The spinal anaesthesia is performed once the fluid loading and the transthoracic echocardiography has been completed.
interventions.comparator: All patients receive 5 ml/kg of 0.9% sodium chloride as a standard fluid loading regime. The control group receives no extra fluids.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Left ventricular volume and function is assesed by transthoracic echocardiography.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline, immediately post intravenous fluid loading, 20 minutes post spinal anaesthesia and 30 minutes post surgery.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Amount and type of vasopressor administered.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: The time from the start to the end of the surgery.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Amount and type of intravenous fluid administered that is separate from the intervention and is dependant on the individual's need during the operation.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: The time from the start to the end of the surgery.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients undergoing elective transurethral resection of the prostate.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Patients with contraindications to spinal anaesthesia. Patients who require invasive cardiac monitoring.

trial_design.concealment: Allocation concealment is achieved by using numbered sealed opaque envelopes which are only opened prior to study protocol commencing.
trial_design.designfeatures: The blinded personnel are as follows. The anaesthetist administering the anaesthesia to the patient. The anaesthetist or echocardiographer who is preforming the transthoracic echocardiogram. The anaesthetists who are reviewing the echocardiogram, assessing outcomes and analysing results. The unblinded personell are the research nurses who will be administering the treatment.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The primary purpose of this study is to find out what dose of intravenous fluid maintains enough fluid volume in the body after a spinal anaesthetic. Particpiants in this study are randomly assigned to have a high dose of intravenous fluid or a low dose of intravenous fluid. We find out how much fluid is in the body by doing an ultrasound of the heart before the the intravenous fluid is given, after the intravenous fluid is given, after the spinal anaesthetic is given and at the end of the operation.
